document_data.name: Samurai
document_data.refs3e: {{Cite dragon/318/Oriental Adventures Update|34}}<ref group="note">The v.3.5 sourcebook ''[[Complete Warrior]]'' also presented a version of the samurai class, which was more general in application, but more specific in provided class abilities. This version of the samurai was proficient in [[heavy armor]]. The "Oriental Adventures Update" article in [[Dragon magazine 318|''Dragon #318'']] describes this as an alternative, not as a replacement, to the class as described in [[Oriental Adventures (3rd edition)|''Oriental Adventures'']].
document_data.mainbody: '''Samurai''' were professional warriors of the noble class who adhered to the code of ''[[bushido]]''.
document_data.Culture:
Samurai were fierce warriors bound by a strict code of honor, and service to their daimyo. They did not fear death, as samurai saw death to be the ultimate honor and service to their daimyo. A samurai's life was consumed by striving to achieve perfection, as it was a reflection of their honor. 

Most samurai were [[human]] or [[spirit folk]]. Some [[korobokuru]] have successfully trained to become samurai.

The samurai's weapon of choice was the [[katana]]. Samurai formed a deep bond with their katana, who saw it as an extension of their honor and the honor of their clan or family. The katana was often a family heirloom, passed down through the generations. It was a serious insult to just touch the [[scabbard]] of a samurai's katana without their explicit permission, drawing the blade even more so. A samurai who lost their katana was disgraced and shamed, and became obsessed with recovering the weapon, if possible.

Organization.Jito: A samurai who was advanced in skill and also served their daimyo well were offered the position of jito. As jito, the samurai was given responsibility over a part of their daimyo's territory. A jito protected their daimyo's property, settled disputes among the civilians, suppressed rebellion and collected taxes on behalf of their daimyo, keeping one-quarter of the taxes for themselves. A jito had command over four samurai and up to ten [[bushi]].
Organization.Shugo: A jito who served well was offered the position of shugo. A shugo was in charge of an entire province, administering justice, providing protection and supervising the jito within the province.
Organization.Ronin: A ronin was a master-less samurai. A ronin could be a samurai who has dishonored them-self, failed their daimyo, or voluntarily left the service of their daimyo.

document_data.Abilities:
Samurai were highly skilled martial warriors. They were experts at both archery and swordsmanship. Their weapons of choice in melee combat were the katana and [[wakizashi]], and they chose the [[daikyu]] for ranged combat.  Some samurai, particularly female samurai, favored the [[naginata]]. A samurai was also an expert horse-rider. 

In addition to their martial prowess, samurai were skilled artists. Calligraphy, music, poetry and painting were among the most common art forms that samurai were known to be accomplished in.

Samurai eventually became immune to ''[[fear]]'' and advanced samurai were capable of naturally projecting an aura of ''fear''. The strongest samurai were able to project ki into their voice, creating a deafening and powerful shout which stunned a target.
